definition.value: Site part of an antigen that is recognized by immune system cells and to which antibodies attach.

Process in which multiple viral disease epidemics of the same type of viral disease unfold over overlapping periods of time and affect organism populations located in different geographic regions, including different countries and continents.
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/vido.owl
Process of viral disease realizations and for which there is a statistically significant increase in the infectious disease incidence of a population.
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/vido.owl
Planned process with the objective to produce information about some evaluant with the purpose of, if justified by the information gathered, managing, directing, or protecting.
Site generated by morphogenetic or physiologic processes that is bounded by an anatomical surface.
Anatomical space that is part of a cell.
Subclinical virus infection with coronavirus as part.
Subclinical coronavirus infection with SARS-CoV-2 as part.
Disposition to inhibit the reproduction of fungi.
Anatomical space through which a pathogen enters an organism.
Anatomical space through which a pathogen exits an organism.
Anatomical space in which an infection appears in a host organism.

A pathogen transporter role that is borne by an organism active in the transfer of an infectious agent or infectious structure to an organism of another species in which it can realize its infectious disposition.
The role is realized in a process that transfers an infectious organism from one location to another.
Disease that occurs in different organs functioning in respiration and consisting especially of the nose, nasal passages, nasopharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, and lungs.
Respiratory system disease located in the lower respiratory tract.
Progressive and life-threatening pulmonary distress in the absence of an underlying pulmonary condition, usually following major trauma or surgery.
Process that generates the ability of a pathogen to induce disorder in an organism.

A Geopolitical Entity that delimits a Government with effective internal and external sovereignty over the region and its population, and which is not dependent on or subject to any other power or Geopolitical Entity.
Information Content Entity that consists of a set of propositions that describe some Entity.
Information Content Entity that consists of a set of symbols that denote some Entity.
Information Content Entity that consists of a set of propositions or images (as in the case of a blueprint) that prescribe some Entity.
A Geospatial Region that is a fiat division of a Geopolitical Entity and not a Geopolitical Entity.
A geospatial region that delimits the authority of a formally constituted government to exercise its control within the bounded area.
A Geospatial Region at which an Entity or Event is located.
A site at or near the surface of the Earth.
A <disposition> that is realised as a harm process.

A <mental disposition> towards repeated episodes of abnormally high levels of motivation to engage in a behaviour, acquired as a result of engaging in the behaviour, where the behaviour results in risk or occurrence of serious net harm.

A mental disposition towards repeated episodes of abnormally high levels of motivation to engage in a behaviour, acquired as a result of engaging in the behaviour, where the behaviour results in risk or occurrence of serious net harm.

This entity focuses on abnormal motivation to engage in a behaviour and includes serious net harm as a feature. The reason is to limit the class to things that merit a treatment and public health response. It is a quantitative entity and a fuzzy set because there can be varying thresholds set for degree of harm and strength of motivation. As a result, it is essential to operationalise the term for it to be meaningful.

While 'addiction' is a disposition relating to experience motivation to use a substance, 'substance dependence' refers to 'disposition related to the impaired functioning in the absence of a substance'.
A person who has reached maturity.
For use in research contexts the minimum age needs to be specified.

The age at which a person is considered an adult will vary in different cultures and for different contexts.  For example, the age at which a person reaches physical maturity may not be the same age at which they are considered legally an adult in their country of residence.  For use in research contexts, the minimum age of an "adult" needs to be specified.
A feeling involving positive affect associated with reduction in a feeling of need.
A subjective emotional feeling involving positive affect associated with reduction in a feeling of need.
A <cognitive representation> of themselves by a person or group.
A cognitive representation of themselves by a person or a group about themselves.
A cognitive representation of themselves by a person or group.
This entity is more than self-identity of an individual as it includes group identity.
An <identity> that a person has about themselves.
An identity that a person has about themselves.

The cognitive representation includes multiple aspects and some of these are social. For example, group memberships, cultural norms. Collective identity as a shared attribute of group is related to this but is separate.
A <subjective affective feeling> involving a strong desire or urge.
A subjective emotional feeling involving a strong desire or urge.
An <identity> that a group holds about itself.
An identity that a group holds about itself.
An ongoing consideration regarding this class is whether a socially shared representation can be said to be purely cognitive.
A person between 13 and 19 years of age.
A person who is between the ages of  13 and 19.
A <self-identity> in which the representation involves a relation between the identity holder and another person or group.
A self-identity that represents a relation between oneself and another person or group.
'Social identity' can involve a sense of one's rank or status in reference to other groups.
This can be either a self-identity or a group identity. Possible relations may include membership , affiliation or antagonism. The group may be a formal group, informal group or collection of people.
A <bodily disposition> which is realised as impaired functioning following reduction or termination of use of a psychoactive substance.
An information content entity that describes the level of motivation involved in an addiction.

While 'addiction' is a disposition relating to experience motivation to use a substance, 'substance dependence' refers to 'disposition related to the impaired functioning in the absence of a substance'.
A <disposition> that is realised as a benefit process.
A planned process in which a BCI is applied in a given context, including BCI engagement and outcome behaviour.
Human behaviour that is an intervention outcome.
An intervention that has the aim of influencing human behaviour.
An aggregate of entities that are not dependent on the intervention but may influence the effect of a BCI on its outcome behaviour.

label.value: behaviour change intervention mechanism of action

definition.value: A process that is causally active in the relationship between a BCI scenario and its outcome behaviour.
An <environmental system> that consists of people, their pets, social and cultural institutions and processes that influence the life of people and social groups.

A <social environmental system> that consists of persons related as members of a domestic group, or a number of domestic groups linked through descent from a common ancestor, marriage,  adoption or other legal arrangements.
A <social environmental system> that consists of persons who share a bond of mutual affection and are in contact or communication.
A <mental capability> acquired through training or practice.
The term 'skill' specifically refers to acquired capabilities, as behavioural theories suggested that the main difference between capabilities and skills was that skills were learned.
A <mental capability> that involves processes that modulate the frequency, rate or extent of a response to external or internal stimuli and that are instigated by the person themselves.
'Modulate’ refers to ‘modifying or controlling influence on or change the strength’ and involves processes
A <self-regulation capability> to modulate one's behaviour.
A <self-regulation capability> to modulate one's cognitive processes.
A <self-regulation capability> to modulate one's emotional responses to a stimulus.
